posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
A severely-injured neurosurgeon seeking a cure for his lost abilities becomes Sorcerer Supreme under the tutelage of the Ancient One.  Employing black arts to transfuse power from other dimensions and the beings that inhabit them, the doctor melds otherworldliness with his martial prowess to defy the malevolence threatening to usurp control of universal balance.

My version has a definite martial bias, drawing on the arcane to fortify his melee prowess.  There's a good reason for that choice.  I've been searching for a sorcerer-oriented build where I could justify the limitations of the known spell library and Dr. Strange seems to fit the bill.  Almost. The self-buffs are near as optimal as a wizard's but gain some advantages that a wizard typically is denied:  excellent universal saves and irresistible weapon damage (somewhat akin to cleric divine buffs but with a dominant arcane epic presence).  

Influenced by his Blackguard's fiendish reputation, the dark mystic is a menace. But to who? Those who seek to undermine the cosmic balance, good or evil.  He is less pure evil in his actions than he is egotistical by nature.  It's that contradiction that prejudices the opinions and trust of his contemporaries and unsteadies his foes.  No creature seems to be able to anticipate either his intent or how he will react to their actions.  This obscurity has many believing his personality is evil though it is only his craft that draws upon dark forces.  We may never be certain what influences hold sway over his conscience or behavior.  The cloaked powers he manipulates result in a dubious repute, at best.

So let's travel back over 50 years to 1963 when comics cost 12 cents, and while we are visiting, examine the trials and tribulations of Dr. Stephen Vincent Strange, the black mystic of the Marvel Age!

PROs
  • UBAB progression
  • Up to 8 APR one-handed by the end of pre-epic
  • Intrinsic AB and AC easily transformed into formidable levels by skills and spells
  • Outstanding saves
  • Key special abilities can be used while polymorphed (lotsa fun watching Tenser turn undead)
  • Can set all deadly traps but gas
  • BG summoning ability spares limited sorc repertoire of those sorts of spells
CONs
  • Late bloomer; momentum in arcane arts unrealized until mid-epic
  • Pixie's trap management delayed until epic (Level 21, specifically)
  • Offensive spells will not penetrate high SR
  • EMA extremely late
  • Typical sorc known spell limitations impact adaptability to specific situations
  • Loss of potency in high-magic environments where high-level item properties, fortified creature skins and dispel spamming is common

Spells
These are the final known spells at Src 22.  Along the way, there are temporary spells that will make pre-epic and early epic levels a bit easier to deal with.  GMW continues to be of use for buffing the pixie's dagger if you use it for preemptive strikes.  However, scrolls of GMW will produce the same benefit, if you can afford them.  You'll need to experiment and play-by-ear as the PC levels for best fit.  The final list reflects the spell combination that has produced the best general success among diverse environments.

Tips

The best tip I can offer... PARTY!  Solves the pre-epic woes for the most part.
  • The first four levels, those before invisible recon, concealment buff and Taunt proficiency is the toughest.
  • Level 5, possess faerie dragon.  MW spell to enchant kama, temporarily.
  • Level 8, begin ability buffs and Flame wpn.  Sacrifice Cat DEX for Darkness, temporarily, unless scrolls are available (sneak damage will add up with high APR and TS).
  • Level 11, Taunt/expertise exploit now available.
  • Level 12, BG Bull STR stacks with sorc Bull STR for extra boost to AB, dmg and Discipline.
  • Level 13, BG undead summon.  If you can buy NEB scrolls, the ghast will last a long time, especially with ability pre-buffs..
  • Levels 14-20  BG sneak dmg and summon quality steadily increase.  During this period, Darkness will guarantee higher damage against most foes (non True seers) and prevent AoOs.
  • Handling traps in pre-epic:  Use faerie dragon to spot traps (Search 9 by Level 8), invisible, if needed.
  • Use either Summon Badger scrolls or familiar to trigger ground traps, elemental ammo for containers/doors.
  • Mobs can be broken up with possessed familiar recon by using edge of enemy perception range and then go ImpInvis when too many chase.  Breaking possession and then immediately unsummoning will leave pursuers dead in their tracks.
  • Starting at Level 22, the combo of Doom Knight/NEB is very powerful among living enemies. At Level 26 the damage/healing from the empowered version can be impressive.
  • Use Iron golem polymorph vs. DevCritters and WMs.
  • When facing AC beyond the reach of your toon's maximum AB even with full taunt success, and since you'll only be able to hit on a natural, DW kamas using FoB mode for 9 APR.  You can use Expertise mode instead, for the additional AC, but lose the extra attack in choosing that option (only one mode can be active).  Your choice.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi Hip - love the premise! I was always a fan of Dr Strange: one of the less predictable characters in Marvel's arsenal. I don't normally comment on spellcaster builds - you know why - though I often read them. But I have just a tiny point (no, it's not just a rumour). You offer ImpCrit: Kama as an alternative to Expertise at level 6, but don't you need a BAB of 8+ to take that feat? Unless I'm missing something, that would mean the earliest you could take it would be level 12.

Regardless, it's one I'm sure I'll come back to once I've developed any sorcerous skills

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Quite right there, Stagmeister!  Good number crunching 

I only played using Keen Edge to expand crit range but knew the feat could be swapped out for Expertise sometime during pre-epic, if desired.  TBH, Expertise was only significant in pre-epic until the Divine Shield could be boosted high enough with buffs and gear.  And then, as late as it comes into play, EMA assures AC will no longer be an issue.  If sticking with Expertise, though, the earlier the better and I'd recommend the original sequence.
